rev.comment: /* 30 January â Arrival of the Army */
rev.diff:
Line 164: Line 164:
By 6:00 am local time, Tahrir Square was quiet with only a few hundred people.<ref name="aj-liveblog30jan">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/29/live-blog-301-egypt-protests|title=Live Blog 30/1 – Egypt Protests|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Later in the morning, 3,000â5,000 protesters were reported as gathering there, including hundreds of state judges protesting for the first time.<ref name="aj-liveblog30jan"/><ref>[http://twitter.com/nolanjazeera Dan Nolan @nolanjazeera].</ref> They, among others, have called for a new [[Constitution of Egypt|constitution]] and a [[transitional government]]. Judges joined the Tahrir demonstrations.<ref name="Egypt's opposition discusses interim government">{{Cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egypts-opposition-discusses-interim-government|title=Egypt's Opposition Discusses Interim Government|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Soldiers were given orders to use [[live ammunition]], but the army said the order would be refused since they were present to "protect the people." According to ''Al Jazeera Arabic'', the army chief told protesters they would not be fired upon. Helicopters were monitoring the protests, and [[fighter jet]]s were repeatedly flying low over the Tahrir Square.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201113033817859936.html|title=Cairo Protesters Stand Their Ground|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> After the first pass of the two [[Egyptian Air Force]] [[F-16]]s, the crowd cheered but subsequent passes triggered louder chants, laughing, and waving. The crowd did not disperse.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2011-01-30-egypt-protests_N.htm|title=Egyptian Demonstrations Calm Down|work=[[USA Today]]|last=Michaels|first=Jim|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Protesters were also reported picking up trash in Tahrir Square, as essential services were not working and that they wanted to "keep our country clean". Food and water were offered at the scene.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Topol|first=Sarah A.|title=The Anti-Mubarak Love Train|url=http://www.tnr.com/article/world/82454/egypt-riots-mubarak-violence-peaceful|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[The New Republic]]|date=30 January 2011}}</ref>
By 6:00 am local time, Tahrir Square was quiet with only a few hundred people.<ref name="aj-liveblog30jan">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/29/live-blog-301-egypt-protests|title=Live Blog 30/1 – Egypt Protests|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Later in the morning, 3,000â5,000 protesters were reported as gathering there, including hundreds of state judges protesting for the first time.<ref name="aj-liveblog30jan"/><ref>[http://twitter.com/nolanjazeera Dan Nolan @nolanjazeera].</ref> They, among others, have called for a new [[Constitution of Egypt|constitution]] and a [[transitional government]]. Judges joined the Tahrir demonstrations.<ref name="Egypt's opposition discusses interim government">{{Cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egypts-opposition-discusses-interim-government|title=Egypt's Opposition Discusses Interim Government|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Soldiers were given orders to use [[live ammunition]], but the army said the order would be refused since they were present to "protect the people." According to ''Al Jazeera Arabic'', the army chief told protesters they would not be fired upon. Helicopters were monitoring the protests, and [[fighter jet]]s were repeatedly flying low over the Tahrir Square.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201113033817859936.html|title=Cairo Protesters Stand Their Ground|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> After the first pass of the two [[Egyptian Air Force]] [[F-16]]s, the crowd cheered but subsequent passes triggered louder chants, laughing, and waving. The crowd did not disperse.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2011-01-30-egypt-protests_N.htm|title=Egyptian Demonstrations Calm Down|work=[[USA Today]]|last=Michaels|first=Jim|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Protesters were also reported picking up trash in Tahrir Square, as essential services were not working and that they wanted to "keep our country clean". Food and water were offered at the scene.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Topol|first=Sarah A.|title=The Anti-Mubarak Love Train|url=http://www.tnr.com/article/world/82454/egypt-riots-mubarak-violence-peaceful|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[The New Republic]]|date=30 January 2011}}</ref>
â
[[File:2011 Egypt protests - sitting line of men.jpg|thumb|Protesters in Tahrir Square. ''Translation'': "Go away Mubarak"]]
+
[[File:2011 Egypt protests - sitting line of men.jpg|thumb|240px|Protesters in Tahrir Square. ''Translation'': "Go away Mubarak"]]
[[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]], Egypt's Minister of Defence and Commander in Chief of the Egyptian Armed Forces, was seen with the protesters in Tahrir Square in downtown Cairo.<ref name="almasryalyoum1">{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egypts-minister-defense-joins-protesters-tahrir-square|title=Egypt's Minister of Defense Joins Protesters in Tahrir Square |work=[[Al-Masry Al-Youm]]|date=|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> As of 18:30, Mohammed ElBaradei had arrived in Tahrir Square and told that crowd that "what we have begun cannot go back".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011130165636218719.html|title=ElBaradei: No Going Back in Egypt |work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> He also said "You are the owners of this revolution. You are the future. Our key demand is the departure of the regime and the beginning of a new Egypt in which each Egyptian lives in virtue, freedom and dignity."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110130/D9L2RQ980.html|title=Egypt Military Steps Up Presence in Chaotic Cairo|publisher=Apnews.myway.com|date=|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> An opposition leader{{Who|date=January 2011}} said that talks would not be held with Mubarak but only with the army.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/01/arab-satelite-network-al-jazeera-has-reported-that-egyptian-opposition-leaders-say-that-their-negotiations-for-a-transition.html|title=Egypt: Opposition Plans To Negotiate with Military, Not President |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> Mubarak was holding a meeting with his military commanders at the time.<ref>{{cite web|last=Salama|first=Vivian|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-30/mubarak-meets-military-commanders-as-protesters-looters-disregard-curfew.html|title=Mubarak Meets Military Commanders as Protesters, Looters Disregard Curfew|work=[[Bloomberg]]|date=|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
[[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]], Egypt's Minister of Defence and Commander in Chief of the Egyptian Armed Forces, was seen with the protesters in Tahrir Square in downtown Cairo.<ref name="almasryalyoum1">{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egypts-minister-defense-joins-protesters-tahrir-square|title=Egypt's Minister of Defense Joins Protesters in Tahrir Square |work=[[Al-Masry Al-Youm]]|date=|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> As of 18:30, Mohammed ElBaradei had arrived in Tahrir Square and told that crowd that "what we have begun cannot go back".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011130165636218719.html|title=ElBaradei: No Going Back in Egypt |work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> He also said "You are the owners of this revolution. You are the future. Our key demand is the departure of the regime and the beginning of a new Egypt in which each Egyptian lives in virtue, freedom and dignity."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110130/D9L2RQ980.html|title=Egypt Military Steps Up Presence in Chaotic Cairo|publisher=Apnews.myway.com|date=|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> An opposition leader{{Who|date=January 2011}} said that talks would not be held with Mubarak but only with the army.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/01/arab-satelite-network-al-jazeera-has-reported-that-egyptian-opposition-leaders-say-that-their-negotiations-for-a-transition.html|title=Egypt: Opposition Plans To Negotiate with Military, Not President |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> Mubarak was holding a meeting with his military commanders at the time.<ref>{{cite web|last=Salama|first=Vivian|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-30/mubarak-meets-military-commanders-as-protesters-looters-disregard-curfew.html|title=Mubarak Meets Military Commanders as Protesters, Looters Disregard Curfew|work=[[Bloomberg]]|date=|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
